questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in the eye and complaints of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step in management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotic eye drops B) Ascorbic eye drops C) Irrigation of the eye with normal saline D) Steroids

options.label: C
options.text: Irrigation of the eye with normal saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Irrigation of the eye with normal saline

questions.text: A factory worker presented with a history of chuna (lime) exposure in both eyes a few hours ago. What is the first immediate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Take history B) Copious irrigation of eyes C) Check vision in both eyes D) Check IOP and plan for surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Check IOP and plan for surgery

questions.explanation:
Chemical Injuries
  • Eye injuries caused by chemicals range from mild irritation to vision loss.
  • Sources of Injury
    • Domestic: Ammonia, detergents, cosmetics
    • Agriculture: Fertilizers, insecticides
    • Laboratory: Acids, alkalis
    • Assaults & Warfare: Acid attacks, chemical weapons
    • Self-inflicted: Malingering or mental health conditions
  • Alkali vs. Acid Burns
    • Alkali: More severe, deeper penetration due to saponification, hygroscopic nature, and soluble compounds formation.
    • Acid: Less severe, protein coagulation forms a protective barrier.

Clinical Stages
  • Acute: Conjunctival swelling, corneal epithelial loss, iris inflammation, possible corneal sloughing and staphyloma.
  • Reparation: Epithelial regeneration, corneal vascularization, iris inflammation subsides.
  • Complications: Symblepharon, recurrent ulcers, cataracts, secondary glaucoma.

Emergency Management
  • Immediate irrigation: Use water or saline for at least 20-30 minutes or until the eye’s pH is restored. A minimum of 2 liters should be used. (Option B)
  • Mechanical removal: Gently remove any chemical particles with a cotton swab, particularly in lime burns.
  • Necrotic tissue removal: Carefully excise dead conjunctiva and corneal epithelium using a cotton swab.

Healing & Complication Prevention
  • Topical antibiotics: Use broad-spectrum antibiotics like moxifloxacin to prevent infection.
  • Topical steroids: Control inflammation and anterior uveitis. Use cautiously after two weeks to avoid hindering collagen production.
  • Cycloplegics: Alleviate pain and dilate the pupil with agents like atropine.
  • Ascorbic acid: Promote wound healing and collagen synthesis using topical and systemic Vitamin C.
  • Lubricants: Use preservative-free artificial tears to keep the eye moist and support healing.
  • Autologous serum: Use serum eye drops to provide essential growth factors for healing.
  • Sodium citrate: Stabilise neutrophils and reduce collagenase activity with topical sodium citrate.
  • Doxycycline: Inhibit collagenase activity with oral doxycycline.
  • Symblepharon Prevention:Use a glass shell or sweep a glass rod in the fornices (spaces between the eyelid and eyeball) twice daily to prevent adhesions.

Complication Management
  • Secondary glaucoma: Control intraocular pressure with beta-blockers like timolol or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide.
  • Limbal stem cell deficiency: Consider amniotic membrane or limbal stem cell transplantation.
  • Pseudopterygium: Surgically remove abnormal conjunctival growth and consider autografting or amniotic membrane transplantation.
  • Corneal opacity: Consider keratoplasty or keratoprosthesis for severe corneal damage.

Implications

Chemical injuries can cause permanent vision loss, physical disfigurement and psychological impact despite treatment.

questions.text: A patient has a history of a flying foreign body injury to the eye. Hemochromatosis is subsequently diagnosed. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the deposition?
questions.explanation:
Intraocular Foreign Bodies (IOFBs)

Description

An IOFB can lodge in any part of the anterior or posterior segments, causing mechanical damage, infection, or toxic effects on intraocular structures.

Types

Inert: Glass, wood, plastic, rubber, gold, silver, platinum

Reactive: Organic and Inorganic (iron causing siderosis, copper causing chalcosis).

Diagnosis

  • History.
  • Examination (wound examination, foreign body location, associated signs such as lid laceration and anterior segment damage should be noted).
  • CT (investigation of choice) with axial and coronal cuts detects and localizes a metallic IOFB.
  • MRI is contraindicated (metallic IOFB).

Treatment

  • Magnetic removal (metallic IOFB)
  • Forceps removal through pars plana vitrectomy
  • Prophylaxis against infection (topical/systemic antibiotics)
  • Conservative and supportive management (topical corticosteroids, analgesics, etc).

questions.text: The patient presents with foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complaints of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step management in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.correct_answer: C. Irrigation of eye with normal saline
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Irrigation of the eye with

questions.text: Which investigation is most suitable for localizing a foreign body in the eye of an industrial worker admitted to the hospital due to an eye injury caused by cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred. (Option C)
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs. (Option A)
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.(Option B)
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the outpatient department with a history of trauma near the eye and now presents with symptoms of fever, severe pain, and swelling in the left eye. On examination, no abnormal findings were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum.

Etiology
  • Sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis (most common) carries a high risk of causing orbital cellulitis. (Option A)
  • Underlying dental problem.
  • Dacryocystitis (inflammation of the lacrimal sac).
  • Endogenous cause: Septicemia
  • Exogenous cause: Fracture or surgery of the orbit.

Causative Organisms
  • Staphylococcus aureus (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae (most common in children)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Streptococcus pyogenes

Clinical Features
  • Preseptal cellulitis: Fever, pain, swelling, tenderness on the outer eyelid region. (Option D)
  • Orbital cellulitis: (Option A)
    • Painful, unilateral Proptosis (swelling and severe pain worsened by eye movement or pressure)
    • Restriction of eye movements (due to proptosis)
    • Decreased visual acuity

Staging

Modified Chandler staging system:

  • Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to the orbital septum) (Option D)
  • Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum)
  • Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess
  • Stage IV: Orbital abscess
  • Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis

 

Treatment

  • Antibiotics (IV): Empirical therapy treats orbital cellulitis by giving Ceftazidime, Vancomycin, and Metronidazole.
  • Monitoring of optic nerve function
  • Surgery: Drainage of an orbital abscess or infected sinuses should be considered if there is a lack of response to antibiotics.

questions.text: A man suffered trauma to the eye from a punch while fighting with another person. What is the most common site of fracture in orbit?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Blow-out orbital fractures result from trauma causing backward displacement of the eyeball and an increase in intraorbital pressure, leading to a resultant fracture.

Classification
  • Pure blow-out fractures: Not associated with involvement of the orbital rim.
  • Impure blow-out fractures: Associated with other fractures in the middle third of the facial skeleton.

Clinical Features
  • Periorbital oedema and blood extravasation (e.g., subconjunctival ecchymosis)
  • Emphysema of the eyelids, more common with medial wall fractures
  • Paraesthesia and anaesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve (lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, and upper teeth)
  • Ipsilateral epistaxis (bleeding from maxillary sinus)
  • Proptosis, often due to orbital oedema and haemorrhage
  • Enophthalmos (due to orbital fat escape, muscle entrapment, and cavity enlargement)
  • Diplopia

Radiography
  • X-ray: Water’s view shows ‘hanging drop’ opacity of the superior maxillary antrum due to herniated orbital contents.
  • CT/MRI: Coronal sections show extent of the fracture and herniation- hanging drop or tear drop sign

Management

General Measures and Medical Treatment:

  • Avoid nose blowing
  • Systemic antibiotics to prevent sinus infection
  • Analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Cold compresses to decrease swelling

Surgical Management:

  • Optimal surgery time: 10-14 days after injury
  • Surgical indications: Persistent diplopia, large herniation, tissue incarceration, enophthalmos >3mm

Orbital Surgeries:

  • Orbitotomy: 4 approaches: anterior, lateral, transfrontal, and temporofrontal
  • Exenteration: Removal of all orbital contents and periorbita through an incision along orbital margins.

questions.text: Can you determine the observation indicated by the arrow in the image provided?
questions.explanation:
Damage Mechanisms
  • Direct Impact: Greatest damage at impact site.
  • Compression Wave Force: Distant damage ("contrecoup").
  • Indirect Force: Damage from impact against orbital walls.

Specific Injuries
  • Cornea: Descemet's membrane tears
  • Conjunctiva: Subconjunctival haemorrhage
  • Anterior Chamber: Hyphema (most common sign), exudates.
  • Iris, Pupil, Ciliary Body: Iridodialysis,Iridodonesis.
  • Lens: Rosette shaped cataract, ectopia lentis, Vossius ring
  • Vitreous: Liquefaction, opacities, detachment.
  • Choroid: choroidal rupture(bucket handle type)
  • Retina: Commotio retinae, Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, Gray white retina due to Berlin's edema.
  • Intraocular Pressure: Traumatic glaucoma, hypotony, ghost cell glaucoma, angle recession glaucoma
  • Traumatic optic neuropathy-RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect)

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - MRI

Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred.
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs.
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: What is the probable cause of bleeding in a patient who experienced a hyphema after being struck in the eye by a tennis ball?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Anterior ciliary artery

Structure

Arterial Supply

Cornea

Avascular

Conjunctiva

Anterior ciliary arteries, branches of ophthalmic artery

Sclera

Posterior ciliary arteries (short and long branches) (Option C)

Iris

Major arterial circle of the iris (circulus arteriosus major) (Option A) formed by anterior ciliary and long posterior ciliary arteries

Ciliary Body

Anterior ciliary arteries and long posterior ciliary arteries

Choroid

Short posterior ciliary arteries

Retina

Central retinal artery

Lens

Avascular

Extraocular Muscles

Muscular branches of the ophthalmic artery (including anterior ciliary arteries)

Eyelids

Ophthalmic artery (superior and inferior palpebral branches), facial artery

Lacrimal Gland

Lacrimal artery

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.correct_answer: A. Removal of the foreign body
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Removal of the foreig
